answer_html: In this case, a single x-value in the domain will be associated with two y-values from the upper and lower half of the circle. This is the same as saying that a circle fails the vertical line test, as a vertical line drawn through any point in the domain will intersect the graph in two places.

In this case, a single \emph{x}-value in the domain will be associated
with two \emph{y}-values from the upper and lower half of the circle.
This is the same as saying that a circle fails the vertical line test,

hints_html: For a relation to be a function, how many y-values can be associated with a single x-value?
hints_latex:
For a relation to be a function, how many \emph{y}-values can be
associated with a single \emph{x}-value?
hints_raw: For a relation to be a function, how many ''y''-values can be associated with a single ''x''-value?
question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
Given a relation or rule that takes input values (usually denoted x) and produces output values (usually denoted y), the relation is a function if each x-value is associated with only one y-value. In other words, the graph of the relation must pass the “vertical line test” - if you can draw a vertical line that intersects the graph at two points, the relation is not a function.

In this case, a single x-value in the domain will be associated with two y-values from the upper and lower half of the circle. This is the same as saying that a circle fails the vertical line test, as a vertical line drawn through any point in the domain will intersect the graph in two places.
sols_latex:
Given a relation or rule that takes input values (usually denoted
\emph{x}) and produces output values (usually denoted \emph{y}), the
relation is a function if each \emph{x}-value is associated with only
one \emph{y}-value. In other words, the graph of the relation must pass
the ``vertical line test'' - if you can draw a vertical line that
intersects the graph at two points, the relation is not a function.

In this case, a single \emph{x}-value in the domain will be associated
with two \emph{y}-values from the upper and lower half of the circle.
This is the same as saying that a circle fails the vertical line test,
as a vertical line drawn through any point in the domain will intersect
the graph in two places.
sols_raw:
Given a relation or rule that takes input values (usually denoted ''x'') and produces output values (usually denoted ''y''), the relation is a function if each ''x''-value is associated with only one ''y''-value.  In other words, the graph of the relation must pass the "vertical line test" - if you can draw a vertical line that intersects the graph at two points, the relation is not a function.  

In this case, a single ''x''-value in the domain will be associated with two ''y''-values from the upper and lower half of the circle.  This is the same as saying that a circle fails the vertical line test, as a vertical line drawn through any point in the domain will intersect the graph in two places.
statement_html:
A circle of radius 5 centered on the origin has the equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x^2 + y^2 = 25\end{aligned}\]

This circle is not a function. Why not?
statement_latex:
A circle of radius 5 centered on the origin has the equation

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle x^2 + y^2 = 25
\end{align*} This circle is not a function. Why not?
statement_raw:
A circle of radius 5 centered on the origin has the equation 
:<math> \displaystyle x^2 + y^2 = 25</math>
This circle is not a function.  Why not?
